text: John Benjamin Hickey (born June 25, 1963) is an American actor with a career in stage, film and television. He won the 2011 Tony Award for Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Play for his performance as Felix Turner in The Normal Heart. ==Early life== Hickey was born in Plano, Texas, and graduated from Plano Sr. High School"Plano Grad and Tony Award Winning Actor Named Honorary Emcee for Ski Plano 2012" pisd.edu, October 3, 2011 in 1981. He attended Texas State University - San Marcos from 1981–1983, where he was active in the theater department. He earned his bachelor's degree in English at Fordham University in 1985.Doyle, Miles. "Fordham Alumnus Wins Tony Award", fordham.edu, June 14, 2011"Hickey Bio", tcm.com, accessed October 18, 2016 ==Career== On Broadway, he originated the role of Arthur in Terrence McNally's play Love! Valour! Compassion! in 1995," 'Love! Valour! Compassion!' Broadway", Playbill, accessed October 18, 2016 a role he recreated for the 1997 film version." 'Love! Valour! Compassion!' Film", tcm.com, accessed October 18, 2016 He played supporting roles in a number of films including The Ice Storm (1997)Hickey Filmography", TCM, accessed October 20, 2016 and The Anniversary Party (2001).The Anniversary Party, AllMovie, accessed October 20, 2016 He has also appeared in Flightplan, Flags of Our Fathers, Freedom Writers, Then She Found Me, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, The Bet and Life with Judy Garland: Me and My Shadows."Life with Judy Garland: Me and My Shadows", TCM, accessed October 18, 2016 He played Clifford Bradshaw in the 1998 Broadway revival of Cabaret, which won the Tony for Best Revival of a Musical. In that same year, he played the lead in the independent film Finding North.Finding North, TCM, accessed October 18, 2016 On Broadway, he played Reverend John Hale in the 2002 revival of Arthur Miller's The Crucible. Hickey played American novelist and playwright Jack Dunphy in the 2006 Truman Capote biopic Infamous.Infamous, TCM, accessed October 18, 2016 Hickey played Philip Stoddard on the short-lived gay-themed sitcom It's All Relative."Out Front Television; All in the Family ", Out, October 2003, Vol. 12, No. 4, ISSN 1062-7928, p. 40 Since It's All Relative, Hickey has appeared on Alias, Law & Order, Brothers & Sisters, Stacked, Heartland, In Plain Sight, Law & Order: Los Angeles, and Modern Family. He appeared in the 2011 Broadway revival of The Normal Heart, for which he won the Tony Award, Featured Actor in a Play."John Benjamin Hickey Broadway" Playbill, accessed October 18, 2016 He was in the Broadway revival of Mary Stuart in 2009, as the Earl of Leicester." 'Mary Stuart' Broadway" ibdb.com, accessed October 20, 2016 From 2010 to 2013, he appeared on The Big C and was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie for the final season of the series,Wieselman, Jarett. "Emmy Hopeful: John Benjamin Hickey - 'The Big C'", etonline.com, June 15, 2012 subtitled Hereafter. Hickey starred as scientist Frank Winter on the TV series Manhattan,Goldberg, Leslie. "'The Big C's' John Benjamin Hickey to Star in WGN America's 'Manhattan'", The Hollywood Reporter, February 6, 2014 which concluded on December 15, 2015 after two seasons and 23 episodes. In 2015, he appeared Off-Broadway at the Mitzi Newhouse Theatre in the play Dada Woof Papa Hot by Peter Parnell.Isherwood. "Review: ‘Dada Woof Papa Hot,’ About Gay Men and Parenthood", The New York Times, November 9, 2015 In 2018 he appeared in the world premiere of Matthew Lopez's new play The Inheritance, inspired by the novel Howards End by E.M. Forster, creating the role Henry Wilcox at London's Young Vic and then transferring to the West End. ==Personal life== Hickey is openly gay. Since 2003 his partner has been screenwriter and television producer Jeffrey Richman. ==Filmography== ===Film=== Source: TCM;"John Benjamin Hickey Filmography", TCM, accessed October 19, 2016 AllMovie"John Benjamin Hickey Filmography", .allmovie.com, accessed October 19, 2016 {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
